introduction.title: How to Make a Ballon Turtle
content: This new balloon sculpture is made with 3 colors and is part of our new tutorial format: <strong>Twist 1 balloon in less thant 3 minutes!</strong
This balloon turtle tutorial has recently been suggested on the French version of this blog article. It's a model I have done regularly and it has been very popular with everyone.

steps: We will need 3 twisting balloons (260s), a green one, a brown one and a white one.
The balloon should not be inflated on both extremities, only in the middle (see images 5 to 9 on the ladybug tutorial).
Fold the ballon in 2 parts and, on the side of the smaller non-inflated margin,, make one bubble smaller than the other one..
Then, on the longer segment, starting from the side of the non-inflated margin, twist a second bubble of almost the same size as the first one (does not have to be exactly the same).
This will automatically create a third bubble in the middle, which we will turn into a loop. This will be the turtle's head.
Take one of the two balloon segments under the loop, and make a first oval bubble (about 2 fingers wide),
followed by a second slightly larger oval bubble (about 3 fingers wide).
Then, do exactly the same thing with the other balloon segment: first a small oval bubble (about 2 fingers wide),
followed by a second slightly larger oval bubble (about 3 fingers wide).
Lock the 2 large bubbles together, then bring the center of the 2 smaller oval bubbles closer to the center of the 2 larger oval bubbles,
in order to lock them together too. These will be the two front legs of the turtle.
Thin out and distribute the air harmoniously in the remaining balloon segments.
If necessary, slide the knot backwards to recover a little more margin (see air pressure control).
before thinning out and distributing the air in the balloon segment where the knot is.
Then take the shortest remaining balloon segment (it doesn't matter if it's the side of the knot or not), and make an oval bubble (about 3 fingers wide).
Then line up the other balloon segment to make a long bubble the same size as the one in front of the last bubble you just made.
Lock these two large bubbles together to make the belly of the turtle.
If necessary, again recover a little margin by sliding the knot backwards.
Make a bubble at the base of the longest of the two remaining balloon segments,
and transform it into a pinch-twist. That will be the little tail of our turtle.
At this stage, you should get a shape similar to this one.
To make the shell, we will inflate the brown balloon except for a margin of about the width of a hand, which will not be inflated.
You must lock the knot of the brown balloon between the head and the front legs of the turtle.
Do not forget to thin out and lengthen the brown balloon.
Make a first bubble the same size as the turtle's belly,
and lock it at the level of the turtle's tail and hind legs.
Make a second bubble and lock it at the level of the head and the front legs.
Don't forget to push the air towards the end of the balloon from time to time.
Then make a third bubble which will be locked at the level of the tail.
And a fourth (make the bubbles a little longer on the sides than those in the middle),
then a fifth one, which will be the last.
Pierce and deflate the remaining balloon segment,
and tie it securely to the tail (or to the head) hiding the surplus balloon.
Rearrange the segments of the belly and of the shell in a harmonious way,
as well as the legs and head of the balloon turtle.
Then take our last white balloon and inflate it a little (about 3 fingers wide).
For the eyes of the turtle, we are going to start with a small bubble,
followed by a second bubble of the same size.
Block the knot on one side, and pass the bubble of the remaining balloon segment over it,
and "roll it around" several times between the two bubbles in order to solidly secure the knot.
Cut the unnecessary balloon excess,
and tie it with the balloon knot so that the two bubbles are firmly attached to each other.
Widen the balloon loop that forms the turtle's head,
in order to slide one of the two white bubbles that we have just made.
Once the bubble is on the other side, position the two white bubbles correctly so that they come out clearly on each side of the loop.
All that remains is to add 2 or 3 pencil strokes (with a felt pen) and you're done!
And here is our lovely little balloon turtle!
